thread.title: Gateshead's De La Rue absorbs £3.7m costs following failed passport contract bid

author: Coreena Ford
title: Gateshead's De La Rue absorbs £3.7m costs following failed passport contract bid
text:
Business Gateshead's De La Rue absorbs £3.7m costs following failed passport contract bid The Team Valley bank note and passport printer highlighted a strong year, despite the disappointment of losing the passport contract Share The De la Rue plant in the Team Valley (Image: newcastle chronicle) Share Get business Thank you for subscribing!
Gateshead’s passport and bank note printer De La Rue absorbed write-off costs of £3.7m following its failed bid to renew its UK passport printing contract, full year results reveal.
The figure is revealed in full year results for the business, the world’s largest banknote printer, which learned it had lost its bid to make the iconic blue passport for the UK Government earlier this year.
The company has printed UK passports from its Team Valley factory for the last 10 years but the Government contract for future printing was issued to Franco-Dutch firm Gemalto.
The decision caused widespread controversy as the contract will involve EU-headquartered Gemalto printing the first batch of blue passports after Brexit, and the move could also put around 200 Gateshead jobs at risk.
The business initially planned to appeal the decision, but then dropped those plans, with boss Martin Sutherland telling how “as a business what we have to do is we have to act in the interests of our staff, of our customers, of our shareholders and we have to focus our efforts and our energies elsewhere”.
Now, De La Rue says it is continuing with the current Government contract, working towards transitioning the work to the new supplier, and looking at ways to be more competitive in this sector. Read More Newcastle academic takes charge of body promoting region's life sciences sector
In full year results for the business, for the year ended March 31, Mr Sutherland said the business remains in a strong position despite losing the bid.
Group revenues were up 7% at £493.9m and adjusted operating profit was down 11% at £62.8m. If the paper business – which has since been divested – is excluded from the figures, turnover rose by 4% and adjusted operating profits were up 7% to £56.9m.
Mr Sutherland highlighted the strength of the firm’s underlying results and its order book. Divesting the paper business has also helped the company achieve its strongest balance sheet for years with net debt reduced by £71m to £49.9m, he said. Read More Google, Sky and Facebook show Gateshead event how tech is changing the world
Mr Sutherland said: “Solid growth in all segments has been offset by strategically focused increases in investment in R&D and sales, which will drive long term sustainable growth.
“While losing the new UK passport tender was disappointing, it does not change our goals, nor does it detract from the underlying performance of the Group which remains strong.
“Adjusted operating profit was 11% lower at £62.8m. A significant reduction in the profitability of the paper business was the major factor causing the profit decline, with the write off of the UK passport bid costs as well as planned investments in R&D and sales being offset in part by additional margin from increased sales and certain provision and accrual releases, where we now have additional information as to the likelihood and amount of potential liabilities.” Read More Avid Technology strikes deal with Jaguar Land Rover in £20m R&D project
It is not clear yet what will happen to the people who work in the Gateshead passport site.
At the time of the contract announcement, Mr Sutherland said the company might try to win other work for the plant. Like us on Facebook
